ygData.subject: Re: [neat] NEAT with Pruning Phase : Positive result
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Derek, ... I posted some details in an earlier message, but to recap I created my own clas (BitImage) to represent the characters during experiments as this

X-Yahoo-Profile: alienseedpod

Hi Derek,

Derek James wrote:

>1) What is your training/evaluation set?  ACSII?  gifs?  What size?
>  
>
I posted some details in an earlier message, but to recap I created my 
own clas (BitImage) to represent the characters during experiments as 
this is more efficient in terms of memory requirements and performance. 
BitImage is just a convienient wrapper for a 2D array of bits. The set 
of BitImages is built at the start of an experiment by using various 
parts of the .Net class framework to write each character to a temporary 
Image from which I can then read the pixel values from and build a 
BitImage object.

I use the Courier New font (plain Courier is not a proper TrueType font 
I believe), size 6. I found this to be the smallest I could go before 
the characters became unrecognisable to the human eye as letters of the 
alphabet. When I extract the characters into a BitImage object I 
actually take the smallest possible area that represents all of the 
characters, this works out to be 7 pixels wide by 9 high, e.g.

lower case 'b'

OO`````
`O`````
`O`OO``
`OO``O`
`O```O`
`O```O`
OOOOO``
```````
```````

lower case 'q'

```````
```````
``OO`OO
`O``OO`
`O```O`
`O```O`
``OOOO`
`````O`
````OOO



So you can see that characters have some whitespace around them because 
I have preserved the relative position of the characters from the 
original Image structure, I have simply trimmed the whitespace that is 
common to all of the characters.

The images are 1 bit plane (black and white).

>2) How are these input into the network?
>
>3) What are the outputs of the network?  Do you have 26 outputs, one
>for each letter?
>  
>
For the experinment I have 1 input for each pixel (7x9=63) and one 
output for each character in the set that the network will be exposed 
to, I can vary this number but I have been using all 26 lower case 
letters, so 26 outputs. For each evaluation I apply each character in 
turn to the input nodes and take the highest output as the network's 
selection - if there is no unique high output then I take this as a 
failure for that character.

You will note that the set of characters is very limited, e.g. there is 
only one representation of each letter, I don't have any dummy or 
'trick' characters and I don't use multiple representations of each 
character. This is all on done on purpose because I didn't want a full 
blown OCR experiment as such, I just wanted a problem domain that could 
be used to test NEATs ability to search through a large connection space 
and that would execute at high speed - this domain achieves those 
requirements.

>I ask because we're in the process of experimenting with OCR as well. 
>We're using 50x50 tiffs, 8 images of each letter, consisting of 3
>different fonts (Courier, New Times Roman, and Ariel).
>  
>
50x50 represnts a massive input space, but since I understand you're 
using a roving eye technique that seems reasonable to me, although 
personally I would be tempted to start a bit smaller. I also recommend 
you adopt Kens suggestion of evolving one network for each character. A 
single output can then indicate if the supplied image is or isn't one 
specific character. Once you have 26 successful networks you can 
manually combine them into one large network with 26 outputs. I recon 
this will greatly increase the chances of finding good networks.

Note that I choose to go for the multiple output route because, again, I 
was specifically looking for a difficult task with a high input/output 
space. If I reduce the char set to 2 or three chars the problem becomes 
a lot simpler and networks are found very quickly - the problem 
difficulty I guess rises exponentially with a linear increase in number 
of chars in the set.

>Thanks,
>

Cheers,

Colin
